<think>
Okay, I need to summarize this document about the Panama–Pacific commemorative coins in 3-5 sentences. Let me start by reading through the document to understand the main points.

The document talks about the five commemorative coins issued in 1915 for the Panama–Pacific International Exposition in San Francisco. They include round and octagonal $50 pieces, which are the highest denomination and largest coins ever made by the U.S. Mint. The octagonal one is unique as the only non-round U.S. coin. 

Then there's background on private gold pieces from the Gold Rush, like Humbert's octagonal coins, which were not legal tender but circulated. The exposition was proposed after the 1906 earthquake, and the coins were part of the event's fundraising. Legislation was passed, and artists like Aitken and Keck designed the coins, though some designs were rejected by the Treasury Secretary. 

The production details mention the use of a private company for hubs, the challenges with the San Francisco Mint's facilities, and the distribution through Farran Zerbe, who had trouble selling them. The coins had low mintage, especially the round $50, and are now valuable, with some selling for hundreds of thousands. 

Key concepts: commemorative coins for the exposition, unique $50 pieces, design controversies, low mintage, historical significance, and their current value. I need to condense this into a concise summary focusing on the main topic and key points without getting too detailed. Make sure to mention the expositions, the coins' uniqueness, design issues, mintage numbers, and their current value.
</think>

The Panama–Pacific commemorative coins, issued in 1915 for the San Francisco exposition celebrating the Panama Canal and Balboa's Pacific discovery, included unique $50 pieces (round and octagonal), the largest and highest-denomination U.S. coins ever struck, with the octagonal design being the only non-round U.S. coin. Designed by artists like Robert Aitken and Charles Keck, the coins faced design rejections and production challenges, leading to low mintage numbers, particularly for the round $50 piece, which became one of the rarest commemorative coins. Despite poor initial sales, they hold significant numismatic value today, with some pieces fetching up to $200,000, and they reflect both the era's artistic ambitions and the historical context of the Panama Canal's completion.

qa_pairs.chunk:
[S1] Panama–Pacific commemorative coins


# Panama–Pacific commemorative coins



The five **Panama–Pacific commemorative coins** were produced in connection with the 1915 Panama–Pacific International Exposition in San Francisco. [S2] Struck at that city's mint, the issue included round and octagonal $50 pieces. [S3] Excepting modern bullion coins, these two gold pieces are the highest denomination ever issued and the largest coins ever struck by the United States Mint. [S4] The octagonal $50 piece is the only U.S. [S5] coin to be issued that is not round. [S6] In January 1915, Congress passed legislation for a silver half dollar, as well as a gold dollar, quarter eagle ($2.50 piece), and two $50 pieces: one round and one octagonal. [S7] The Mint had already consulted artists. [S8] Treasury Secretary William G. [S9] McAdoo initially rejected all their designs. [S10] Two of them, Robert Ingersoll Aitken for the $50 pieces and Charles Keck for the gold dollar, persevered, and their submissions were used. [S11] The half dollar and quarter eagle were designed by Chief Engraver Charles E. [S12] Barber, possibly with the participation of his longtime assistant, George T. [S13] Morgan. [S14] The coins were vended at the Exposition by prominent numismatist Farran Zerbe. [S15] They did not sell well, and many of each denomination were returned for melting. [S16] Only a few hundred of each of the $50 pieces were distributed, making them the lowest-mintage commemorative coins. [S17] They catalog for up to $200,000, depending on condition. [S18] ## Background

Private gold pieces, sometimes dubbed "pioneer gold", were struck several times during the 19th century from locally produced bullion in areas where federal coins were scarce. [S19] These unofficial coins came from sites ranging from Georgia to Oregon. [S20] Many, ranging in denomination from 25 cents to 50 dollars, are relics of the California Gold Rush and its aftermath. [S21] The fifty-dollar denomination was struck by private minters such as Kellogg and Co. [S22] The private $50 pieces were round in form, but those struck by Augustus Humbert for the U.S. [S23] Assay Office at San Francisco, prior to the establishment of the San Francisco Mint in 1854, were octagonal. [S24] Humbert's pieces were not money in a legal sense, as Congress had not authorized them as legal tender, and were officially deemed ingots. [S25] Nevertheless, they contained their full value in gold. [S26] Bearing the denomination "Fifty Dollars", they were called "slugs" or "quintuple eagles" by the public. [S27] They circulated widely in California and elsewhere in the Far West, and were accepted on par with federal gold coins. [S28] All of these $50 pieces, public or private, are very rare and valuable today: One of Humbert's octagonal pieces, dated 1851 and with a lettered edge, sold at auction in 2010 for $546,250. [S29] The only $50 piece produced by the United States Bureau of the Mint prior to 1915 was the 1877 pattern half union, produced experimentally at the Philadelphia Mint, though it was not approved as a circulating coin. [S30] In 1904, San Francisco merchant Rueben Hale proposed an exposition in his home city for 1915, both to commemorate the opening of the Panama Canal and to mark the 400th anniversary of Vasco Núñez de Balboa becoming the first European known to view the Pacific Ocean from the Americas: in phrasing then current, he discovered the Pacific. [S31] Although the 1906 San Francisco earthquake and fire caused a momentary setback to these plans, it actually sparked additional fundraising. [S32] Many of the wealthiest in California gave financial support, the state matched private donations dollar for dollar, and in 1911, President William Howard Taft selected San Francisco over its competitor, New Orleans, to host the fair.

qa_pairs.chunk:
[S1] In 1904, San Francisco merchant Rueben Hale proposed an exposition in his home city for 1915, both to commemorate the opening of the Panama Canal and to mark the 400th anniversary of Vasco Núñez de Balboa becoming the first European known to view the Pacific Ocean from the Americas: in phrasing then current, he discovered the Pacific. [S2] Although the 1906 San Francisco earthquake and fire caused a momentary setback to these plans, it actually sparked additional fundraising. [S3] Many of the wealthiest in California gave financial support, the state matched private donations dollar for dollar, and in 1911, President William Howard Taft selected San Francisco over its competitor, New Orleans, to host the fair. [S4] The Panama–Pacific International Exposition, constructed in San Francisco by the Golden Gate at a cost of $50 million, was open from February 20, 1915, to December 4, 1915. [S5] About 19,000,000 people attended, and the exposition was a great success, generating enough profit to build the San Francisco Civic Auditorium with about $1 million remaining. [S6] The Palace of Fine Arts is the only building from the fair which remains on the site. [S7] Commemorative coins were not then sold to the public by the Mint, as they subsequently have been. [S8] Instead, a commemorative's authorizing legislation would designate a group or organization to purchase the coins from the Mint at face value, and sell them to the public as a fundraiser. [S9] Among those who had pushed for commemorative legislation in the past, and had been involved in the sale of the resulting coins, was Farran Zerbe, a collector and numismatic promoter who had by 1914 served as president of the American Numismatic Association. [S10] Zerbe was a controversial figure—some felt the coins with which he had been involved had been sold at inflated prices—but he helped promote the hobby with his exhibit, "Money of the World", which later became part of the Chase Manhattan Money Museum. [S11] ## Legislation

Several proposals for commemorative coins had been introduced by mid-1914, though none had been issued by the Mint since 1905. [S12] One, sponsored by New York Senator Elihu Root, called for a commemorative quarter dollar marking a century of peace, as well as the August 1914 opening of the Panama Canal. [S13] Two bills were introduced calling for coins to commemorate and benefit the Panama–Pacific Exposition; H.R. [S14] 16902 was introduced by California Congressman Julius Kahn on June 3, 1914. [S15] Senate bill (S.) 6309 was introduced in that body by New Jersey Senator James E. [S16] Martine on July 6. [S17] This bill called for two $50 pieces (one round, one octagonal), a quarter eagle or $2.50 in gold, a commemorative gold dollar, and a half dollar. [S18] The octagonal pieces were intended to recall the unofficial $50 coins struck during the Gold Rush

[S1] Martine on July 6. [S2] This bill called for two $50 pieces (one round, one octagonal), a quarter eagle or $2.50 in gold, a commemorative gold dollar, and a half dollar. [S3] The octagonal pieces were intended to recall the unofficial $50 coins struck during the Gold Rush

Martine's bill passed the Senate on August 3, having been approved by the Committee on Industrial Expositions, to which it had been referred. [S4] The only objection was procedural, by Utah's Reed Smoot: that the bill should have instead been referred to and approved by the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency, or its Committee on Finance. [S5] Neither Smoot nor any other senator objected to the bill itself, which Martine indicated had the support of Treasury Secretary William G. [S6] McAdoo. [S7] S. [S8] 6309 was the following day sent to the House of Representatives, where it was referred to the Committee on Coinage, Weights and Measures. [S9] It emerged from that committee on September 1, 1914, with several amendments, one of which increased the combined authorized mintage of the two $50 pieces from 2,000 to 3,000. [S10] S. [S11] 6309 was briefly considered by the House of Representatives on January 4, 1915, and passed after Kahn successfully proposed a minor amendment to strike out the dollar sign from the phrase "silver coins of the denomination of $50 cents each". [S12] The Senate concurred in the House amendments two days later, passing the bill without question, change, or opposition, and President Woodrow Wilson signed it into law on January 16. [S13] ## Preparation

Once Kahn's bill was introduced in the House, Mint Director George E. [S14] Roberts began to make informal arrangements to prepare for the commemorative issue. [S15] The bill called for four different designs (the two $50 pieces would differ mainly in shape), plus a commemorative medal to be sold to fairgoers, with an award medal to be given to prizewinning exhibitors. [S16] All of these pieces were to be struck by the Bureau of the Mint, and Roberts asked the Commission of Fine Arts to recommend artists. [S17] Among those recommended were Adolph A. [S18] Weinman (who would design the Mercury dime and Walking Liberty half dollar in 1916), and Bela L. [S19] Pratt (creator of the 1908 Indian Head gold pieces). [S20] Others included sculptors Evelyn Beatrice Longman, Robert I. [S21] Aitken, Charles Keck, and Paul Manship. [S22] Roberts wrote to several of the sculptors, and found Aitken interested in creating the $50 pieces. [S23] The Mint Director's tentative negotiations with Aitken for the large gold coins and with Buffalo nickel designer James Earl Fraser for the award medal ended when Roberts resigned in November to take a banking job; McAdoo appointed Dr. [S24] Frederic Dewey as Acting Director of the Mint. [S25] Dewey and McAdoo did little regarding the Panama–Pacific coins until Congress began to pass the authorizing legislation in early January 1915. [S26] Once it had passed both houses, and was awaiting Wilson's signature, Dewey arranged for a meeting in New York with Aitken, Keck, Longman, and Manship. [S27] The authorizing act required the Mint to begin delivering coins by the opening date of the fair, February 20, 1915, and although this proved impractical, the Mint still acted quickly. [S28] McAdoo approved the choices of Aitken for the $50 pieces, Longman for the quarter eagle, Keck for the dollar, and Manship for the half dollar on January 21. [S29] All four artists were already at work, and Aitken responded to the notification of his hiring by submitting designs, which were similar to the actual coins.

[S13] ## Preparation

Once Kahn's bill was introduced in the House, Mint Director George E. [S14] Roberts began to make informal arrangements to prepare for the commemorative issue. [S15] The bill called for four different designs (the two $50 pieces would differ mainly in shape), plus a commemorative medal to be sold to fairgoers, with an award medal to be given to prizewinning exhibitors. [S16] All of these pieces were to be struck by the Bureau of the Mint, and Roberts asked the Commission of Fine Arts to recommend artists. [S17] Among those recommended were Adolph A. [S18] Weinman (who would design the Mercury dime and Walking Liberty half dollar in 1916), and Bela L. [S19] Pratt (creator of the 1908 Indian Head gold pieces). [S20] Others included sculptors Evelyn Beatrice Longman, Robert I. [S21] Aitken, Charles Keck, and Paul Manship. [S22] Roberts wrote to several of the sculptors, and found Aitken interested in creating the $50 pieces. [S23] The Mint Director's tentative negotiations with Aitken for the large gold coins and with Buffalo nickel designer James Earl Fraser for the award medal ended when Roberts resigned in November to take a banking job; McAdoo appointed Dr. [S24] Frederic Dewey as Acting Director of the Mint. [S25] Dewey and McAdoo did little regarding the Panama–Pacific coins until Congress began to pass the authorizing legislation in early January 1915. [S26] Once it had passed both houses, and was awaiting Wilson's signature, Dewey arranged for a meeting in New York with Aitken, Keck, Longman, and Manship. [S27] The authorizing act required the Mint to begin delivering coins by the opening date of the fair, February 20, 1915, and although this proved impractical, the Mint still acted quickly. [S28] McAdoo approved the choices of Aitken for the $50 pieces, Longman for the quarter eagle, Keck for the dollar, and Manship for the half dollar on January 21. [S29] All four artists were already at work, and Aitken responded to the notification of his hiring by submitting designs, which were similar to the actual coins.

[S4] By January 29, all four artists had submitted bronze casts of their proposals. [S5] Dewey forwarded them to McAdoo, who solicited advice from the Commission of Fine Arts (which liked them), his Assistant Secretary, William Malburn (who did not), and Chief Engraver Charles E. [S6] Barber and others at the Philadelphia Mint (who offered suggestions). [S7] McAdoo had asked that the Mint prepare alternative designs for all the coins, and Barber did so, starting with the half dollar. [S8] Rejections to all four of the outside artists were sent on February 5 over McAdoo's signature. [S9] The reasons for this are uncertain, as the rejections are terse—Anthony Swiatek and Walter Breen, in their volume on commemoratives, assert that Malburn's opposition was decisive. [S10] All four outside artists protested. [S11] Manship's objections were to no avail; McAdoo selected the design submitted by Barber for the half dollar. [S12] Longman asked for an explanation, submitted new designs, and came to Washington to discuss the matter. [S13] According to a letter several months later from Dewey, she fell ill there and was unable to participate further; numismatic historian Roger Burdette finds the explanation odd and suggests that there may have been some other reason. [S14] Barber was selected to design the quarter eagle. [S15] Both Atiken and Keck objected to the Commission of Fine Arts and to McAdoo; Keck also submitted additional designs. [S16] Both men met with McAdoo, Malburn and Dewey in Washington, and agreed to changes to their proposed designs. [S17] With that done, the $50 and $1 pieces were approved on March 6, 1915. [S18] The half dollar was approved two days later. [S19] Barber submitted his designs for the quarter eagle on March 16. [S20] They met an enthusiastic reception at the Treasury Department, and were approved. [S21] ## Designs


### Barber's half dollar and quarter eagle

To what extent Mint Assistant Engraver (later Chief Engraver) George T. [S22] Morgan should be credited for work on the half dollar and quarter eagle is uncertain; Mint officials and employees were not consistent on this point. [S23] Assistant Director Mary M. [S24] O'Reilly said in 1936 that the bureau's records indicated that Barber was the designer. [S25] Later the same year, she forwarded a statement by an unnamed Philadelphia Mint employee stating that by the very nature of Barber's and Morgan's long association (Morgan was Barber's assistant for 37 years), the two engravers would have conferred frequently, and that Morgan's technique is "very obvious on both sides of both coins". [S26] The employee concluded that "no mistake could be made, in my opinion, in crediting both men with the execution of these two coins. [S27] I am certain that this is correct." Q. [S28] David Bowers, in his book on commemoratives, mentions the dispute, credits Barber on the obverses of both coins, and gives both men credit on the reverse of the half dollar. [S29] He asserts Morgan created the reverse of the quarter eagle.

Charles Keck's obverse for the dollar was one of the alternative designs submitted to McAdoo, depicting the unadorned, capped head of a Panama Canal construction worker—Keck's original concept had featured Poseidon, god of the sea in Greek mythology. [S14] The worker, who represents the labor necessary to build the canal, is sometimes mistaken for a baseball player. [S15] Keck's reverse contains the words "Panama–Pacific Exposition", "San Francisco", the denomination of the coin, and two dolphins, symbolizing the joining of the Atlantic and Pacific oceans by the canal. [S16] The mint mark is beneath the letters D and O in "Dollar". [S17] Vermeule called Keck's dollar "a novel, daring use of the limited area afforded by such a small, thin coin. [S18] Compared with the earlier gold dollars, the coin is a work of art." [S1] Vermeule called Keck's dollar "a novel, daring use of the limited area afforded by such a small, thin coin. [S2] Compared with the earlier gold dollars, the coin is a work of art." Numismatist Arlie Slabaugh, in his volume on commemoratives, noted that the Panama–Pacific dollar "presents a bold American design, completely different from the classical styles used on the other denominations". [S3] Aitken explained his design for the $50 pieces:

> In order to express in my design the fact that this coin is struck to commemorate the Panama–Pacific Exposition, and as the exposition stands for all that wisdom and industry have produced, I have used as the central motive [motif] of the obverse, the head of the virgin goddess Minerva. [S4] She is the goddess of wisdom, of skill, of contemplation ... [S5] Moreover, she features prominently on the seal of the State of California ... [S6] the use of the dolphins on the octagonal coin do much to add to its charm, as well as express the uninterrupted water route made possible by the canal. [S7] Upon the reverse I use the owl, the bird sacred to Minerva, also the symbol of wisdom ... [S8] With these simple symbols, all full of beauty in themselves, I feel that I have expressed the larger meaning of the exposition, its appeal to the intellect. [S9] The goddess wears a crested helmet, as her Greek equivalent, Pallas Athena, was commonly depicted on ancient coins; it is pushed back to signify her peaceful intentions. [S10] She wears mail, which Swiatek and Breen found an odd anachronism. [S11] She bears upon her shield the Roman numerals MCMXV for the year 1915, the second use of Roman numerals on U.S. [S12] coins after the early types of the 1907 Saint-Gaudens double eagle. [S13] Though Aitken had originally expressed the date as "1915" in his original sketches, he soon changed his mind, "As these designs will not be used in any other year, there will be no need to change the year as we must on other coins."

Kevin Flynn, in his book on commemorative coins, described the branch on which the owl perches as that of a ponderosa pine tree; several cones are visible. [S14] The design on the octagonal piece is smaller than on the round, to allow space for the border featuring the dolphins. [S15] The mint mark is on the reverse, adjacent to the rightmost pine cone and directly above the letter "O" in "San Francisco". [S16] The design for the $50 received contemporary criticism; some suggested that the presence of the dolphins on the octagonal coin implied that the canal had been constructed for cetacean convenience. [S17] A 1916 column in the *American Journal of Numismatics* contained the conclusion that "the criticism often heard that 'there is nothing American about the coin except the inscription' is fully warranted." Swiatek and Breen dismissed criticisms as "numerous and mostly irrelevant, based on total misreading of the iconography. [S18] [McAdoo began it] with stupid claims that Pallas Athena meant nothing on a U.S. [S19] coin unless she could be identified with Liberty, and that Athena's owl would never mean anything to all of us". [S20] Vermeule deemed the $50 coins "a tour de force, dated to be sure, but unusual enough in all respects to be worthy of what American numismatic art could achieve". [S21] Later Chief Engraver Elizabeth Jones felt that the $50 pieces were "stylistically in step with the period [and have] considerable artistic merits". [S22] Jeff Garrett and Ron Guth, in their book on U.S. [S23] gold coins, deemed the Panama–Pacific $50 pieces "one of the most stunning issues ever produced by the U.S. [S24] government". Once the designs were approved, the artists prepared bronze casts to be sent to the Medallic Art Company in New York. [S4] There, hubs would be made that the Mint could use to produce coinage dies, as the company could do it faster than could the Mint. [S5] The Panama–Pacific issues are the first American coins known to have been produced from hubs provided by a private company—the Medallic Art Company prepared hubs for the 1913 Buffalo nickel, but it is uncertain if they were used. [S6] The Panama–Pacific hubs were sent to the Philadelphia Mint, where the Engraving Department, headed by Barber, would produce the necessary dies. [S7] Although the authorizing statute required that the coins be struck in San Francisco, all coinage dies at that time were produced by Barber and his assistants in Philadelphia. [S8] By April, Robert W. [S9] Woolley had been commissioned as Director of the Mint, and he approved samples of the gold dollar, the first to have work completed, on April 22. [S10] He then traveled to San Francisco, and was there when the dies for the dollar arrived on the 27th. [S11] When the San Francisco Mint's coiner examined them, they proved to be lacking the mint mark "S", customary on coins produced there. [S12] Woolley was not sure if this was intentional, and wired to Philadelphia Mint Superintendent Adam M. [S13] Joyce on the 29th. [S14] Upon learning that it was intentional—Joyce reasoned that as the entire mintage of this, the first commemorative issue to be struck outside Philadelphia, would be produced at San Francisco, there was no need to use a mint mark—Woolley ordered that the dies at San Francisco and in transit be returned to Philadelphia, and new ones produced with the mint mark. [S15] Woolley believed that people would assume the coins were struck at Philadelphia, which did not then use a mint mark. [S16] Burdette notes that the San Francisco Mint was a source of local pride and the omission of the mint mark would likely have led to widespread protest, and possibly to two varieties of each of the new coins: with mint mark, and without. [S17] New dollar dies were sent from Philadelphia on May 3, and for the half dollar the following day. [S18] Dies for the $50 followed on May 14, and for the quarter eagle on May 27. [S19] Containing 2.4286 troy ounces (2.6645 oz; 75.54 g) of gold and measuring 44.9 millimetres (1.77 in) across for the octagonal) and 43 millimetres (1.7 in) in diameter for the round, the $50 pieces were the largest and heaviest U.S. [S20] coins issued until surpassed in 2010 by the America the Beautiful silver bullion coins. [S21] The octagonal $50 piece is the only U.S. [S22] coin that is not round. [S23] The facilities at the San Francisco Mint were inadequate to strike such large coins as the $50 pieces, and a hydraulic medal press was shipped from Philadelphia. [S24] This press was ceremoniously operated at that mint on June 15, 1915 for the initial striking of $50 octagonal pieces; the first by San Francisco Mint Superintendent T. [S25] W. [S26] H. [S27] Shanahan, for presentation to the exposition's president, Charles C. [S28] Moore. [S29] The next nine were struck by other dignitaries, including Congressman Kahn. [S30] Anyone else present with the price of $100 per coin was then allowed to strike their own piece, and at least three people, including Dewey's wife and the local postmaster, did so.

[S1] Moore. [S2] The next nine were struck by other dignitaries, including Congressman Kahn. [S3] Anyone else present with the price of $100 per coin was then allowed to strike their own piece, and at least three people, including Dewey's wife and the local postmaster, did so. [S4] The Panama–Pacific Exposition Company hired Farran Zerbe to sell the new coins at the fair. [S5] Despite the provisions of the law mandating a delivery of coins before the fair's opening, the only government products Zerbe initially had to vend at his "Money of the World" exhibit were a souvenir medal, designed by Aitken and struck by a press operating at the Mint's exhibit, and prints produced by the Bureau of Engraving and Printing, also on-site. [S6] Sales of the medal were slow, and Zerbe did not have coins to sell until soon after May 8, 1915, when the half dollar and dollar dies were received. [S7] Zerbe found the coins hard to sell; many potential purchasers, faced with a plethora of medals, reproductions of Gold Rush-era pioneer gold coins, and other wares from a variety of vendors, did not believe his coins were official government products. [S8] Treasury officials agreed to allow him space for a salesperson at the Mint's exhibit, and the two lower denominations were sold there, with orders taken for the $50 pieces. [S9] Soon, though, Zerbe stopped selling the gold dollar there, and the rest of the fair's run was marked by conflict between him and Treasury representatives. [S10] The full legal allocation for each denomination had been struck, but though Zerbe continued selling coins by mail after the fair closed on December 4, 1915, sales dropped through 1916. [S11] Zerbe continued to sell coins on behalf of the exposition until at least November 1916, and at some point, he sold an unknown quantity to himself to supply the future needs of his coin business. [S12] The remainder were melted by the Treasury. [S13] The Mint struck 1,500 of each of the two $50 pieces, plus nine extra of the octagonal and ten of the round, to be sent to Philadelphia to await the 1916 meeting of the annual Assay Commission, when they would be available for inspection and testing. [S14] Zerbe had arranged for special display boxes and cases. [S15] A set of four denominations (with the purchaser's choice of round or octagonal for the $50) cost $100; a set of five cost $200. [S16] Copper display frames with two of each coin were said by Slabaugh to have cost $400, but Swiatek, in his 2011 book on commemoratives, indicates that these sets may actually have been given to dignitaries, as no sales receipts or correspondence relating to them are known. [S17] A set of the three smaller denominations sold for $7, the half dollar at $1, the gold dollar at $2 or $2.25 (prices may have varied), and the quarter eagle at $4 each.
